<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Disneyland_Resort_sidebar&amp;action=edit"><span title="Edit this template" style="">e</span></a></li>

<p><b>Disneyland Park</b>, originally <b>Disneyland</b>, is the first of two <a href="/wiki/Theme_park" title="Theme park" class="mw-redirect">theme parks</a> built at the <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Resort" title="Disneyland Resort">Disneyland Resort</a> in <a href="/wiki/Anaheim,_California" title="Anaheim, California">Anaheim, California</a>, opened on July 17, 1955. It is the only theme park designed and built under the direct supervision of <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney" title="Walt Disney">Walt Disney</a>. It was originally the only attraction on the property, though it was slightly renamed to distinguish it from the expanding complex in the 1990s.</p>
<p>Walt Disney came up with the concept of Disneyland after visiting various amusement parks with his daughters in the 1930s and 1940s. He initially envisioned building a tourist attraction adjacent to his <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_(Burbank)" title="Walt Disney Studios (Burbank)">studios</a> in <a href="/wiki/Burbank,_California" title="Burbank, California">Burbank</a> to entertain fans who wished to visit; however, he soon realized that the proposed site was too small. After hiring a consultant to help determine an appropriate site for his project, Walt bought a 160-acre (65&#160;ha) site near Anaheim in 1953. Construction began in 1954 and the park was unveiled during a special televised press event on the ABC Television Network on July 17, 1955.</p>
<p>Since its opening, Disneyland has undergone a number of expansions and renovations, including the addition of <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans_Square" title="New Orleans Square">New Orleans Square</a> in 1966, <a href="/wiki/Critter_Country" title="Critter Country">Bear Country</a> (now Critter Country) in 1972, and <a href="/wiki/Mickey%27s_Toontown" title="Mickey's Toontown">Mickey's Toontown</a> in 1993. <a href="/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure_Park" title="Disney California Adventure Park" class="mw-redirect">Disney California Adventure Park</a> was built on the site of Disneyland's original parking lot and opened in 2001.</p>
<p>Disneyland has a larger cumulative attendance than any other theme park in the world, with over 650 million guests since it opened. In 2011, the park hosted approximately 16.14 million guests, making it the second most visited park in the world that calendar year.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_attendance_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_attendance-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> According to a March 2005 report from the Disney Company, there are 65,700 Jobs supported by the Disneyland Resort.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Dedication">Dedication</span></h2>
<blockquote class="templatequote">
<p><i>To all who come to this happy place: Welcome. Disneyland is your land. Here age relives fond memories of the past, and here youth may savor the challenge and promise of the future. Disneyland is dedicated to the ideals, the dreams, and the hard facts that have created America, with the hope that it will be a source of joy and inspiration to all the world.</i></p>
<div class="templatequotecite">°™<a href="/wiki/Walter_E._Disney" title="Walter E. Disney" class="mw-redirect">Walter E. Disney</a>, July 17, 1955, 4:43&#160;pm<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></div>
</blockquote>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:WaltDisneyplansDisneylandDec1954.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Walt Disney with Orange County officials" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/WaltDisneyplansDisneylandDec1954.jpg/220px-WaltDisneyplansDisneylandDec1954.jpg" width="220" height="195" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/WaltDisneyplansDisneylandDec1954.jpg/330px-WaltDisneyplansDisneylandDec1954.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/WaltDisneyplansDisneylandDec1954.jpg/440px-WaltDisneyplansDisneylandDec1954.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:WaltDisneyplansDisneylandDec1954.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Walt Disney (center) showing Orange County officials plans for Disneyland's layout, December 1954.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The concept for Disneyland began when Walt Disney was visiting <a href="/wiki/Griffith_Park" title="Griffith Park">Griffith Park</a> in Los Angeles with his daughters Diane and Sharon. While watching them ride the <a href="/wiki/Merry-go-round" title="Merry-go-round" class="mw-redirect">merry-go-round</a>, he came up with the idea of a place where adults and their children could go and have fun together, though his dream lay dormant for many years.<sup id="cite_ref-Dreaming_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dreaming-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> He may have also been influenced by his father's memories of the <a href="/wiki/World%27s_Columbian_Exposition" title="World's Columbian Exposition">World's Columbian Exposition</a> of 1893 in Chicago (his father worked at the Exposition). The <a href="/wiki/Midway_Plaisance" title="Midway Plaisance">Midway Plaisance</a> there included a set of attractions representing various countries from around the world and others representing various periods of man; it also included many rides including the first <a href="/wiki/Ferris_wheel" title="Ferris wheel">Ferris wheel</a>, a "sky" ride, a passenger train that circled the perimeter, and a Wild West Show. Another likely influence was <a href="/wiki/Benton_Harbor,_Michigan" title="Benton Harbor, Michigan">Benton Harbor, Michigan</a>'s nationally famous <a href="/wiki/House_of_David_(commune)" title="House of David (commune)">House of David</a>'s Eden Springs Park. Disney visited the park and ultimately bought one of the older miniature trains originally used there; the colony had the largest miniature railway setup in the world at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>While people wrote letters to Disney about visiting the <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_(Burbank)" title="Walt Disney Studios (Burbank)">Walt Disney Studios</a>, he realized that a functional movie studio had little to offer to visiting fans, and began to foster ideas of building a site near the <a href="/wiki/Burbank,_California" title="Burbank, California">Burbank</a> studios for tourists to visit. His ideas evolved to a small play park with a boat ride and other themed areas. The initial concept, the Mickey Mouse Park, started with an 8-acre (3.2&#160;ha) plot across Riverside Drive. He started to visit other parks for inspiration and ideas, including <a href="/wiki/Tivoli_Gardens,_Copenhagen" title="Tivoli Gardens, Copenhagen" class="mw-redirect">Tivoli Gardens</a> in Denmark, <a href="/wiki/Efteling" title="Efteling">Efteling</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Netherlands" title="Kingdom of the Netherlands">The Netherlands</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Henry_Ford" title="The Henry Ford">Greenfield Village</a>, <a href="/wiki/Playland_(San_Francisco)" title="Playland (San Francisco)">Playland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Children%27s_Fairyland" title="Children's Fairyland">Children's Fairyland</a> in the United States.<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> His designers began working on concepts, though the project grew much larger than the land could hold.<sup id="cite_ref-JustDisney_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JustDisney-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> Disney hired Harrison Price from <a href="/wiki/Stanford_Research_Institute" title="Stanford Research Institute" class="mw-redirect">Stanford Research Institute</a> to gauge the proper area to locate the theme park based on the area's potential growth. With the report, Disney acquired 160&#160;acres (65&#160;ha) of orange groves and walnut trees in Anaheim, southeast of Los Angeles in neighboring <a href="/wiki/Orange_County,_California" title="Orange County, California">Orange County</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-JustDisney_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JustDisney-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-harrison_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harrison-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template"><span title="&#160;since March 2013" style="white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot" title="Wikipedia:Link rot">dead link</a></i>]</span></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_aerial_view_in_1956.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Disneyland from the air in 1956." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Disneyland_aerial_view_in_1956.jpg/220px-Disneyland_aerial_view_in_1956.jpg" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Disneyland_aerial_view_in_1956.jpg/330px-Disneyland_aerial_view_in_1956.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Disneyland_aerial_view_in_1956.jpg/440px-Disneyland_aerial_view_in_1956.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_aerial_view_in_1956.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
An aerial view of Disneyland in 1956, with the Disneyland Railroad route visible.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Difficulties in obtaining funding prompted Disney to investigate new methods of fundraising, deciding to create a show named <i><a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_anthology_series" title="Walt Disney anthology series" class="mw-redirect">Disneyland</a>.</i> It was broadcast on then-fledgling <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a>. In return, the network agreed to help finance the park. For its first five years of operation, Disneyland was owned by <a href="/wiki/Disneyland,_Inc." title="Disneyland, Inc.">Disneyland, Inc.</a>, which was jointly owned by <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Productions" title="Walt Disney Productions" class="mw-redirect">Walt Disney Productions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney" title="Walt Disney">Walt Disney</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Publishing" title="Western Publishing">Western Publishing</a> and ABC.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> In addition, Disney rented out many of the shops on Main Street, U.S.A. to outside companies. By 1960, Walt Disney Productions bought out all other shares, a partnership which would eventually lead to the Walt Disney Corporation's acquisition of ABC in the mid-1990s. In 1952, the proposed project had been called Disneylandia, but Disney followed ABC's advice and changed it to Disneyland two years later, when excavation of the site began.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> Construction began on July 16, 1954 and cost $17 million to complete. The park was opened one year and one day later.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/U.S._Route_101" title="U.S. Route 101">U.S. Route 101</a> (later <a href="/wiki/Interstate_5" title="Interstate 5">Interstate 5</a>) was under construction at the same time just north of the site; in preparation for the traffic Disneyland was expected to bring, two more lanes were added to the freeway before the park was finished.<sup id="cite_ref-harrison_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harrison-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Disneyland was dedicated at an "International Press Preview" event held on Sunday, July 17, 1955, which was only open to invited guests and the media. Although 28,000 people attended the event, only about half of those were actual invitees, the rest having purchased counterfeit tickets.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> The following day, it opened to the public, featuring twenty attractions. The Special Sunday events, including the dedication, were televised nationwide and anchored by three of Walt Disney's friends from Hollywood: <a href="/wiki/Art_Linkletter" title="Art Linkletter">Art Linkletter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bob_Cummings" title="Bob Cummings" class="mw-redirect">Bob Cummings</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>. ABC broadcast the event live, though many guests tripped over the camera cables.<sup id="cite_ref-koening2006_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-koening2006-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> In Frontierland, a camera caught Cummings kissing a dancer. When Disney started to read the plaque for Tomorrowland, he read partway then stopped when a technician off-camera said something to him, and after realizing he was on-air, said, "I thought I got a signal",<sup id="cite_ref-koening2006_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-koening2006-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> and began the dedication from the start. At one point, while in Fantasyland, Linkletter tried to give coverage to Cummings, who was on the pirateship. He was not ready, and tried to give the coverage back to Linkletter, who had lost his microphone. Cummings then did a play-by-play of him trying to find it in front of Mr. Toad's Wild Ride.<sup id="cite_ref-koening2006_13-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-koening2006-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Traffic was delayed on the two-lane Harbor Boulevard.<sup id="cite_ref-koening2006_13-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-koening2006-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> Famous figures who were scheduled to show up every two hours showed up all at once. The temperature was an unusually high <span style="white-space:nowrap;">101 °„F</span> <span style="white-space:nowrap;">(38&#160;°„C)</span>, and because of a local plumbers' strike, Disney was given a choice of having working drinking fountains or running toilets. He chose the latter, leaving many drinking fountains dry. This generated negative publicity since <a href="/wiki/Pepsi" title="Pepsi">Pepsi</a> sponsored the park's opening; disappointed guests believed the inoperable fountains were a cynical way to sell soda, while other vendors ran out of food. The asphalt that had been poured that morning was soft enough to let ladies' high-heeled shoes sink into it. A gas leak in <a href="/wiki/Fantasyland" title="Fantasyland">Fantasyland</a> caused <a href="/wiki/Adventureland_(Disney)" title="Adventureland (Disney)">Adventureland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frontierland" title="Frontierland">Frontierland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fantasyland" title="Fantasyland">Fantasyland</a> to close for the afternoon. Some parents threw their children over the crowd's shoulders to get them onto rides, such as the <a href="/wiki/King_Arthur_Carrousel" title="King Arthur Carrousel">King Arthur Carrousel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> In later years, Disney and his 1955 executives referred to July 17, 1955 as "Black Sunday".</p>
<p>After the extremely negative press from the preview opening, Walt Disney invited attendees back for a private "second day" to experience Disneyland properly. The next day, crowds gathered in line as early as 2:00&#160;am. The first person to buy a ticket and enter the park was David MacPherson with ticket number 2, as <a href="/wiki/Roy_O._Disney" title="Roy O. Disney">Roy O. Disney</a> arranged to pre-purchase ticket number 1 from Curtis Lineberry, the manager of admissions. However, an official picture of Walt Disney and two children, Christine Vess Watkins (age 5) and Michael Schwartner (7), inaccurately identifies them as the first two guests of Disneyland. Both received lifetime passes to Disneyland that day, and MacPherson was awarded one shortly thereafter, which was later expanded to every single Disney-owned park in the world. Approximately 50,000 guests attended the Monday opening day.<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:6308-AnaheimDisneyLand-NW_to_SE_View.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/6308-AnaheimDisneyLand-NW_to_SE_View.jpg/220px-6308-AnaheimDisneyLand-NW_to_SE_View.jpg" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/6308-AnaheimDisneyLand-NW_to_SE_View.jpg/330px-6308-AnaheimDisneyLand-NW_to_SE_View.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/6308-AnaheimDisneyLand-NW_to_SE_View.jpg/440px-6308-AnaheimDisneyLand-NW_to_SE_View.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:6308-AnaheimDisneyLand-NW_to_SE_View.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Aerial view of Disneyland in 1963, looking southeast. The Santa Ana Freeway (I-5) is in the upper left corner. Harbor Boulevard forms the eastern boundary of the park. The newly completed Melodyland Theater is at the top of the picture.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In September 1959, Soviet Premier <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> spent thirteen days in the United States, with two requests: to visit Disneyland and to meet <a href="/wiki/John_Wayne" title="John Wayne">John Wayne</a>, Hollywood's top box-office draw. Due to the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> tension and security concerns, he was famously denied an excursion to Disneyland.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi" title="Mohammad Reza Pahlavi">The Shah of Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Empress_Farah" title="Empress Farah" class="mw-redirect">Empress Farah</a> were invited to Disneyland by Walt Disney in early 1960s. There was moderate controversy over the lack of African American employees. Since 1963, <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights" title="Civil rights" class="mw-redirect">civil rights</a> activists pressured Disneyland to hire black people, with executives responding that they would "consider" the requests. Despite a lack of black employees, the park hired <a href="/wiki/Asian_American" title="Asian American">people of Asian descent</a>, like <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ty_Wong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ty Wong (page does not exist)">Ty Wong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bob_Kuwahara" title="Bob Kuwahara">Bob Kuwahara</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>As part of the Casa de Fritos operation at Disneyland, "<a href="/wiki/Doritos" title="Doritos">Doritos</a>" (Spanish for "little golden things") were created at the park to help use old tortillas that were being discarded. The Frito-Lay Company saw the popularity of the item and decided to sell them regionally in 1964, and then nationwide in 1966.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the late 1990s, work began to expand the one-park, one-hotel property. Disneyland Park, the Disneyland Hotel, the site of the original parking lot, and acquired surrounding properties were earmarked to become part of the <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Resort" title="Disneyland Resort">Disneyland Resort</a>. At this time, the property saw the addition of the <a href="/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure" title="Disney California Adventure">Disney California Adventure</a> theme park, a shopping, dining and entertainment complex named <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Disney_(California)" title="Downtown Disney (California)" class="mw-redirect">Downtown Disney</a>, a remodeled <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Hotel_(California)" title="Disneyland Hotel (California)">Disneyland Hotel</a>, the construction of <a href="/wiki/Disney%27s_Grand_Californian_Hotel_%26_Spa" title="Disney's Grand Californian Hotel &amp; Spa">Disney's Grand Californian Hotel &amp; Spa</a>, and the acquisition and re-branding of the Pan Pacific Hotel as <a href="/wiki/Disney%27s_Paradise_Pier_Hotel" title="Disney's Paradise Pier Hotel">Disney's Paradise Pier Hotel</a>. At this time, the park was renamed as Disneyland Park to distinguish it from the larger complex under construction. Because the existing parking lot (south of Disneyland) was built upon by these projects, the six-level, 10,250-space Mickey and Friends parking structure was constructed in the northwest corner. At the time of its completion in 2000, it was the largest parking structure in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The park's management team during the mid-1990s was a source of controversy among fans and employees. In an effort to boost profits, various changes were begun by then-executives <a href="/wiki/Cynthia_Harriss" title="Cynthia Harriss">Cynthia Harriss</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paul_Pressler" title="Paul Pressler">Paul Pressler</a>. While their actions provided a short-term increase in shareholder returns, they drew widespread criticism for the lack of foresight. With the retail background of Harriss and Pressler, Disneyland's focus gradually shifted from attractions to merchandising. Outside consultants <a href="/wiki/McKinsey_%26_Company" title="McKinsey &amp; Company">McKinsey &amp; Company</a> were brought in to help streamline operations, resulting in many changes and cutbacks. After nearly a decade of deferred maintenance, the original park was showing signs of neglect. Fans of the park decried the perceived decline in customer value and park quality and rallied for the dismissal of the management team.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_Annaheim.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Disneyland in 2005" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Disneyland_Annaheim.JPG/220px-Disneyland_Annaheim.JPG" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Disneyland_Annaheim.JPG/330px-Disneyland_Annaheim.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Disneyland_Annaheim.JPG/440px-Disneyland_Annaheim.JPG 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_Annaheim.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
An aerial view of Disneyland in 2005</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Matt_Ouimet" title="Matt Ouimet">Matt Ouimet</a>, the former president of the <a href="/wiki/Disney_Cruise_Line" title="Disney Cruise Line">Disney Cruise Line</a>, was promoted to assume leadership of the Disneyland Resort in late 2003. Shortly afterward, he selected <a href="/wiki/Greg_Emmer" title="Greg Emmer">Greg Emmer</a> as Senior Vice President of Operations. Emmer is a long-time Disney cast member who had worked at Disneyland in his youth prior to moving to Florida and held multiple executive leadership positions at the <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_World" title="Walt Disney World">Walt Disney World Resort</a>. Ouimet quickly set about reversing certain trends, especially with regards to cosmetic maintenance and a return to the original infrastructure maintenance schedule, in hopes of restoring the safety record of the past. Much like Walt Disney, Ouimet and Emmer could often be seen walking the park during business hours with members of their respective staff, wearing cast member name badges, standing in line for attractions, and welcoming guests' comments. In July 2006, Matt Ouimet left The Walt Disney Company to become president of <a href="/wiki/Starwood_Hotels_%26_Resorts_Worldwide" title="Starwood Hotels &amp; Resorts Worldwide" class="mw-redirect">Starwood Hotels &amp; Resorts Worldwide</a>. Soon after, <a href="/wiki/Ed_Grier" title="Ed Grier">Ed Grier</a>, executive managing director of Walt Disney Attractions Japan, was named president of the resort, though he retired from his job on February 8, 2008. In October 2009, Grier announced his retirement, and was replaced by George Kalogridis.</p>
<p>The "<a href="/wiki/Happiest_Homecoming_on_Earth" title="Happiest Homecoming on Earth">Happiest Homecoming on Earth</a>" was an eighteen-month-long celebration (held through 2005 and 2006) of the fiftieth anniversary of the Disneyland Park, also celebrating Disneyland's milestone throughout Disney parks worldwide. In 2004, the park underwent major renovations in preparation, restoring many classic attractions were restored, notably <a href="/wiki/Space_Mountain_(Disneyland,_Anaheim)" title="Space Mountain (Disneyland, Anaheim)" class="mw-redirect">Space Mountain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jungle_Cruise" title="Jungle Cruise">Jungle Cruise</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Haunted_Mansion" title="Haunted Mansion">Haunted Mansion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_(attraction)" title="Pirates of the Caribbean (attraction)">Pirates of the Caribbean</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney%27s_Enchanted_Tiki_Room" title="Walt Disney's Enchanted Tiki Room">Walt Disney's Enchanted Tiki Room</a>. Attractions that had been in the park on opening day had one ride vehicle painted gold, and the park was decorated with fifty <a href="/wiki/Hidden_Mickey_50_Ears" title="Hidden Mickey 50 Ears" class="mw-redirect">Golden Mickey Ears</a>. The celebration started on May 5, 2005 and ended on September 30, 2006, and was followed by the "Year of a Million Dreams" celebration, lasting twenty-seven months and ending on December 31, 2008.</p>
<p>Beginning on January 1, 2010, Disney Parks hosted the <a href="/wiki/Give_a_Day,_Get_a_Disney_Day" title="Give a Day, Get a Disney Day">Give a Day, Get a Disney Day</a> volunteer program, in which Disney encouraged people to volunteer with a participating charity and receive a free Disney Day at either a Disneyland Resort or Walt Disney World park. On March 9, 2010, Disney announced that it had reached its goal of one million volunteers and ended the promotion to anyone who had not yet registered and signed up for a specific volunteer situation.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Lands">Lands</span></h2>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Disneyland_attractions" title="List of Disneyland attractions">List of Disneyland attractions</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_former_Disneyland_attractions" title="List of former Disneyland attractions">List of former Disneyland attractions</a></div>
<p>Disneyland Park consists of eight themed "lands" and a number of concealed backstage areas, and occupies approximately 85&#160;acres (34&#160;ha).<sup id="cite_ref-JustDisney_7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JustDisney-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> The park opened with <i><a href="/wiki/Main_Street,_U.S.A." title="Main Street, U.S.A.">Main Street, U.S.A.</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Adventureland_(Disney)" title="Adventureland (Disney)">Adventureland</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Frontierland" title="Frontierland">Frontierland</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Fantasyland" title="Fantasyland">Fantasyland</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Tomorrowland" title="Tomorrowland">Tomorrowland</a></i>, and has since added <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans_Square" title="New Orleans Square">New Orleans Square</a> in 1966, Bear Country (later <a href="/wiki/Critter_Country" title="Critter Country">Critter Country</a>) in 1972, and <a href="/wiki/Mickey%27s_Toontown" title="Mickey's Toontown">Mickey's Toontown</a> in 1993. In 1957, <a href="/wiki/Holidayland_(Disneyland)" title="Holidayland (Disneyland)">Holidayland</a>, opened to the public with a 9&#160;acres (3.6&#160;ha) recreation area including a <a href="/wiki/Circus" title="Circus">circus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baseball_diamond" title="Baseball diamond" class="mw-redirect">baseball diamond</a>, but was closed in late 1961. It is often referred to as the "lost" land of Disneyland. Throughout the park are '<a href="/wiki/Hidden_Mickey" title="Hidden Mickey">Hidden Mickeys</a>', representations of Mickey Mouse heads inserted subtly into the design of attractions and environmental decor. An elevated <a href="/wiki/Berm" title="Berm">berm</a> supports a <a href="/wiki/Narrow_gauge_railway" title="Narrow gauge railway">narrow gauge railroad</a> that circumnavigates the park.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Main_Street.2C_U.S.A.">Main Street, U.S.A.</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_Main_Street.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Main Street in 2010" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Disneyland_Main_Street.jpg/220px-Disneyland_Main_Street.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Disneyland_Main_Street.jpg/330px-Disneyland_Main_Street.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Disneyland_Main_Street.jpg/440px-Disneyland_Main_Street.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_Main_Street.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Main Street, U.S.A. on July 4, 2010</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Main_Street,_U.S.A." title="Main Street, U.S.A.">Main Street, U.S.A.</a></div>
<p>Main Street, U.S.A. is patterned after a typical <a href="/wiki/Midwest" title="Midwest" class="mw-redirect">Midwest</a> town of the early 20th century. Walt Disney derived inspiration from his boyhood town of <a href="/wiki/Marceline,_Missouri" title="Marceline, Missouri">Marceline, Missouri</a> and worked closely with designers and architects to develop the Main Street appeal. It is the first area guests see when they enter the park (if not entering by monorail), and is how guests reach Central Plaza. At the center of The Magic Kingdom and immediately North of Central Plaza stands <a href="/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty_Castle" title="Sleeping Beauty Castle">Sleeping Beauty Castle</a>, which provides entrance to Fantasyland by way of a drawbridge across a moat. Adventureland, Frontierland, and Tomorrowland are arrayed on both sides of the castle.</p>
<table align="center" style="border-collapse:collapse; border-style:none; background-color:transparent;" class="cquote2">
<tr>
<td width="20" valign="top" style="color:#B2B7F2;font-size:40px;font-family:serif;font-weight:bold;text-align:left;padding:10px 10px;">°∞</td>
<td valign="top" style="padding:4px 10px;">For those of us who remember the carefree time it recreates, Main Street will bring back happy memories. For younger visitors, it is an adventure in turning back the calendar to the days of grandfather's youth.</td>
<td width="20" valign="bottom" style="color:#B2B7F2;font-size:40px;font-family:serif;font-weight:bold;text-align:right;padding:10px 10px;">°±</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>&#160;</td>
<td valign="top">
<div style="line-height:1em;text-align: right"><cite style="font-style:normal;">°™ Walt E. Disney</cite></div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Main Street, U.S.A. is reminiscent of the Victorian period of America with the train station, town square, movie theater, city hall, firehouse complete with a steam-powered pump engine, emporium, shops, arcades, double-decker bus, horse-drawn streetcar, jitneys and other bits of memorabilia. Main Street is also home to the Disney Art Gallery and the Opera House which showcases <i>Great Moments with Mr. Lincoln</i> a show featuring an <a href="/wiki/Audio-Animatronic" title="Audio-Animatronic" class="mw-redirect">Audio-Animatronic</a> version of the president. There are many specialty stores on Main Street including: a candy store, jewelry and watch shop, a silhouette station, a store that sells Disney collectable items created by various artists, and a hat shop where you have the option of creating your own ear hat along with a personalized embroidery. At the far end of Main Street, U.S.A. is <a href="/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty_Castle" title="Sleeping Beauty Castle">Sleeping Beauty Castle</a>, and the Central Plaza (also known as the Hub), which is a portal to most of the themed lands. Several lands are not directly connected to the Central Plaza°™namely, <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans_Square" title="New Orleans Square">New Orleans Square</a>, <a href="/wiki/Critter_Country" title="Critter Country">Critter Country</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mickey%27s_Toontown" title="Mickey's Toontown">Mickey's Toontown</a>.</p>
<p>The design of Main Street, U.S.A. uses the technique of <a href="/wiki/Forced_perspective" title="Forced perspective">forced perspective</a> to create an illusion of height. Buildings along Main Street are built at <span class="frac nowrap">?</span> scale on the first level, then <span class="frac nowrap">?</span> on the second story, and <span class="frac nowrap">?</span> scale on the third°™reducing the scale by <span class="frac nowrap">?</span> each level up.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Adventureland">Adventureland</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Adventureland_Disneyland.JPG" class="image"><img alt="photo of Adventureland" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Adventureland_Disneyland.JPG/220px-Adventureland_Disneyland.JPG" width="220" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Adventureland_Disneyland.JPG/330px-Adventureland_Disneyland.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Adventureland_Disneyland.JPG/440px-Adventureland_Disneyland.JPG 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Adventureland_Disneyland.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Adventureland provides a 1950s view of adventure, capitalizing on the post-war <a href="/wiki/Tiki" title="Tiki">Tiki</a> craze.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Adventureland_(Disney)" title="Adventureland (Disney)">Adventureland (Disney)</a></div>
<p>Adventureland is designed to recreate the feel of an exotic tropical place in a far-off region of the world. "<i>To create a land that would make this dream reality</i>", said Walt Disney, "<i>we pictured ourselves far from civilization, in the remote <a href="/wiki/Jungle" title="Jungle">jungles</a> of Asia and Africa.</i>" Attractions include opening day's <a href="/wiki/Jungle_Cruise" title="Jungle Cruise">Jungle Cruise</a>, the "Temple of the Forbidden Eye" in <a href="/wiki/Indiana_Jones_Adventure" title="Indiana Jones Adventure" class="mw-redirect">Indiana Jones Adventure</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Family_Treehouse" title="Swiss Family Treehouse">Tarzan's Treehouse</a>, which is a conversion of the earlier <i>Swiss Family Robinson Tree House</i> from the Walt Disney film, <i><a href="/wiki/Swiss_Family_Robinson_(film)" title="Swiss Family Robinson (film)" class="mw-redirect">Swiss Family Robinson</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney%27s_Enchanted_Tiki_Room" title="Walt Disney's Enchanted Tiki Room">Walt Disney's Enchanted Tiki Room</a> which is located at the entrance to Adventureland is the first feature attraction to employ <a href="/wiki/Audio-Animatronics" title="Audio-Animatronics">Audio-Animatronics</a>, a computer synchronization of sound and robotics.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="New_Orleans_Square">New Orleans Square</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Adventureland_at_Disneyland_IMG_3879_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="photo of New Orleans Square" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Adventureland_at_Disneyland_IMG_3879_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Adventureland_at_Disneyland_IMG_3879_%28cropped%29.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Adventureland_at_Disneyland_IMG_3879_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Adventureland_at_Disneyland_IMG_3879_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Adventureland_at_Disneyland_IMG_3879_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Adventureland_at_Disneyland_IMG_3879_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Adventureland_at_Disneyland_IMG_3879_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Haunted_Mansion" title="Haunted Mansion">Haunted Mansion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fantasmic!" title="Fantasmic!">Fantasmic!</a> viewing area in New Orleans Square (2010)</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans_Square" title="New Orleans Square">New Orleans Square</a></div>
<p>New Orleans Square is based on 19th-century <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a>, opened on July 24, 1966. Despite its age, it is still very popular with Disneyland guests, as it is home to some of the park's most popular attractions: <i><a href="/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_(theme_park_ride)" title="Pirates of the Caribbean (theme park ride)" class="mw-redirect">Pirates of the Caribbean</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Haunted_Mansion" title="Haunted Mansion">Haunted Mansion</a></i>, with nighttime entertainment in <i><a href="/wiki/Fantasmic!" title="Fantasmic!">Fantasmic!</a></i>. This area is the home of the famous <a href="/wiki/Club_33" title="Club 33">Club 33</a>.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Frontierland">Frontierland</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Big_Thunder_Mountain_Railroad.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Big Thunder Mountain Railroad" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Big_Thunder_Mountain_Railroad.JPG/220px-Big_Thunder_Mountain_Railroad.JPG" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Big_Thunder_Mountain_Railroad.JPG/330px-Big_Thunder_Mountain_Railroad.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Big_Thunder_Mountain_Railroad.JPG/440px-Big_Thunder_Mountain_Railroad.JPG 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Big_Thunder_Mountain_Railroad.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Big_Thunder_Mountain_Railroad" title="Big Thunder Mountain Railroad">Big Thunder Mountain Railroad</a> in Frontierland (2008)</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Frontierland" title="Frontierland">Frontierland</a></div>
<p><b>Frontierland</b> recreates the setting of pioneer days along the <a href="/wiki/American_frontier" title="American frontier">American frontier</a>. According to Walt Disney, "<i>All of us have cause to be proud of our country's history, shaped by the pioneering spirit of our forefathers. Our adventures are designed to give you the feeling of having lived, even for a short while, during our country's pioneer days.</i>" Frontierland is home to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pinewood_Indians&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pinewood Indians (page does not exist)">Pinewood Indians</a> band of animatronic Native Americans, who live on the banks of the <a href="/wiki/Rivers_of_America_(Disney)" title="Rivers of America (Disney)">Rivers of America</a>. Entertainment and attractions include <a href="/wiki/Big_Thunder_Mountain_Railroad" title="Big Thunder Mountain Railroad">Big Thunder Mountain Railroad</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mark_Twain_Riverboat" title="Mark Twain Riverboat">Mark Twain Riverboat</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sailing_Ship_Columbia" title="Sailing Ship Columbia">Sailing Ship Columbia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pirate%27s_Lair_on_Tom_Sawyer_Island" title="Pirate's Lair on Tom Sawyer Island">Pirate's Lair on Tom Sawyer Island</a>, and Frontierland Shootin' Exposition. Frontierland is also home to the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horseshoe_Saloon" title="Golden Horseshoe Saloon">Golden Horseshoe Saloon</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Old_West" title="Old West" class="mw-redirect">Old West</a>-style show palace, where the comedic troupe "<a href="/wiki/Billy_Hill_and_the_Hillbillies" title="Billy Hill and the Hillbillies">Billy Hill and the Hillbillies</a>" entertains guests.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Critter_Country">Critter Country</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SplashMountain(2).JPG" class="image"><img alt="Splash Mountain" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c8/SplashMountain%282%29.JPG/220px-SplashMountain%282%29.JPG" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c8/SplashMountain%282%29.JPG/330px-SplashMountain%282%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c8/SplashMountain%282%29.JPG/440px-SplashMountain%282%29.JPG 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:SplashMountain(2).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Splash Mountain is a combination log flume and dark ride attraction, based on the 1946 Disney film <i><a href="/wiki/Song_of_the_South" title="Song of the South">Song of the South</a></i>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Critter_Country" title="Critter Country">Critter Country</a></div>
<p><b>Critter Country</b> opened in 1972 as "Bear Country", and was renamed in 1988. Formerly the area was home to Indian Village, where indigenous tribespeople demonstrated their dances and other customs. Today, the main draw of the area is <a href="/wiki/Splash_Mountain" title="Splash Mountain">Splash Mountain</a>, a log-flume journey inspired by the <a href="/wiki/Uncle_Remus" title="Uncle Remus">Uncle Remus</a> stories of <a href="/wiki/Joel_Chandler_Harris" title="Joel Chandler Harris">Joel Chandler Harris</a> and the animated segments of Disney's Academy Award-winning 1946 film, <i><a href="/wiki/Song_of_the_South" title="Song of the South">Song of the South</a></i>. In 2003, a <a href="/wiki/Dark_ride" title="Dark ride">dark ride</a> called <a href="/wiki/The_Many_Adventures_of_Winnie_the_Pooh_(attraction)" title="The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh (attraction)">The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh</a> replaced the <a href="/wiki/Country_Bear_Jamboree" title="Country Bear Jamboree">Country Bear Jamboree</a>, which closed in 2001. The attraction is still open in <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_World" title="Walt Disney World">Walt Disney World</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Magic_Kingdom" title="Magic Kingdom">Magic Kingdom</a>.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fantasyland">Fantasyland</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_Fantasyland_IMG_3950.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Attractions in FantasylandPeter Pan's Flight and the Matterhorn in Fantasyland" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Disneyland_Fantasyland_IMG_3950.jpg/220px-Disneyland_Fantasyland_IMG_3950.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Disneyland_Fantasyland_IMG_3950.jpg/330px-Disneyland_Fantasyland_IMG_3950.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Disneyland_Fantasyland_IMG_3950.jpg/440px-Disneyland_Fantasyland_IMG_3950.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_Fantasyland_IMG_3950.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Fantasyland" title="Fantasyland">Fantasyland</a></div>
<p><b>Fantasyland</b> is the area of Disneyland of which Walt Disney said, <cite>"<i>What youngster has not dreamed of flying with <a href="/wiki/Peter_Pan" title="Peter Pan">Peter Pan</a> over moonlit London, or tumbling into Alice's nonsensical <a href="/wiki/Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland" title="Alice's Adventures in Wonderland">Wonderland</a>? In Fantasyland, these classic stories of everyone's youth have become realities for youngsters&#160;®C of all ages&#160;®C to participate in.</i>"</cite> Fantasyland was originally styled in a medieval European fairground fashion, but its 1983 refurbishment turned it into a <a href="/wiki/Bavaria" title="Bavaria">Bavarian</a> village. Attractions include several <a href="/wiki/Dark_ride" title="Dark ride">dark rides</a>, the <a href="/wiki/King_Arthur_Carrousel" title="King Arthur Carrousel">King Arthur Carrousel</a>, and various family attractions. Fantasyland has the most <a href="/wiki/Fiber_optics" title="Fiber optics" class="mw-redirect">fiber optics</a> in the park; more than half of them are in <a href="/wiki/Peter_Pan%27s_Flight" title="Peter Pan's Flight">Peter Pan's Flight</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> Sleeping Beauty's Castle features a walk-through story telling of Briar Rose's adventure as Sleeping Beauty. The attraction opened in 1959, was redesigned in 1972, closed in 1992 for reasons of security and the new installation of pneumatic ram firework shell mortars for "Believe, There's Magic in the Stars", and reopened 2008 with new renditions and methods of storytelling and the restored work of <a href="/wiki/Eyvind_Earle" title="Eyvind Earle">Eyvind Earle</a> (not <a href="/wiki/Mary_Blair" title="Mary Blair">Mary Blair</a>).<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mickey.27s_Toontown">Mickey's Toontown</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_IMG_3967.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photo of Mickey's Toontown" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Disneyland_IMG_3967.jpg/220px-Disneyland_IMG_3967.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Disneyland_IMG_3967.jpg/330px-Disneyland_IMG_3967.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Disneyland_IMG_3967.jpg/440px-Disneyland_IMG_3967.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_IMG_3967.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Mickey's Toontown</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mickey%27s_Toontown" title="Mickey's Toontown">Mickey's Toontown</a></div>
<p><b>Mickey's Toontown</b> opened in 1993 and was partly inspired by the fictional Los Angeles suburb of Toontown in the <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_(Burbank)" title="Walt Disney Studios (Burbank)">Walt Disney Studios</a>' 1988 release <i><a href="/wiki/Who_Framed_Roger_Rabbit" title="Who Framed Roger Rabbit">Who Framed Roger Rabbit</a></i>. Mickey's Toontown is based on a 1930s cartoon aesthetic and is home to Disney's most popular cartoon characters. Toontown features two main attractions: <a href="/wiki/Gadget%27s_Go_Coaster" title="Gadget's Go Coaster">Gadget's Go Coaster</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roger_Rabbit%27s_Car_Toon_Spin" title="Roger Rabbit's Car Toon Spin">Roger Rabbit's Car Toon Spin</a>. The "city" is also home to cartoon character's houses such as the house of <a href="/wiki/Mickey_Mouse" title="Mickey Mouse">Mickey Mouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minnie_Mouse" title="Minnie Mouse">Minnie Mouse</a> and <a href="/wiki/Goofy" title="Goofy">Goofy</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Donald_Duck" title="Donald Duck">Donald Duck</a>'s boat.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tomorrowland">Tomorrowland</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Busy_Tomorrowland_July_16_2009_myjedilightsaber_Cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Space Mountain" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Busy_Tomorrowland_July_16_2009_myjedilightsaber_Cropped.jpg/220px-Busy_Tomorrowland_July_16_2009_myjedilightsaber_Cropped.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Busy_Tomorrowland_July_16_2009_myjedilightsaber_Cropped.jpg/330px-Busy_Tomorrowland_July_16_2009_myjedilightsaber_Cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Busy_Tomorrowland_July_16_2009_myjedilightsaber_Cropped.jpg/440px-Busy_Tomorrowland_July_16_2009_myjedilightsaber_Cropped.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Busy_Tomorrowland_July_16_2009_myjedilightsaber_Cropped.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Space_Mountain_(Disneyland)" title="Space Mountain (Disneyland)">Space Mountain</a> in Tomorrowland (2009)</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tomorrowland" title="Tomorrowland">Tomorrowland</a></div>
<p>During the 1955 inauguration Walt Disney dedicated Tomorrowland with these words: "<i>Tomorrow can be a wonderful age. Our scientists today are opening the doors of the <a href="/wiki/Space_Age" title="Space Age">Space Age</a> to achievements that will benefit our children and generations to come. The Tomorrowland attractions have been designed to give you an opportunity to participate in adventures that are a living blueprint of our future.</i>"</p>
<p>Disneyland producer <a href="/wiki/Ward_Kimball" title="Ward Kimball">Ward Kimball</a> had <a href="/wiki/Aerospace_engineering" title="Aerospace engineering">rocket scientists</a> <a href="/wiki/Wernher_von_Braun" title="Wernher von Braun">Wernher von Braun</a>, Willy Ley, and Heinz Haber serve as technical consultants during the original design of Tomorrowland.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> Initial attractions included <a href="/wiki/Mission_to_Mars_(attraction)" title="Mission to Mars (attraction)"><i>Rocket to the Moon</i></a>, Astro-Jets and <a href="/wiki/Autopia" title="Autopia">Autopia</a>; later, the first incarnation of the <a href="/wiki/Submarine_Voyage" title="Submarine Voyage">Submarine Voyage</a> was added. The area underwent a major transformation in 1967 to become <i>New Tomorrowland</i>, and then again in 1998 when its focus was changed to present a "retro-future" theme reminiscent of the illustrations of <a href="/wiki/Jules_Verne" title="Jules Verne">Jules Verne</a>.</p>
<p>Current attractions include <a href="/wiki/Space_Mountain_(Disneyland)" title="Space Mountain (Disneyland)">Space Mountain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Innoventions_(Disneyland)" title="Innoventions (Disneyland)">Innoventions</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Captain_EO_Tribute" title="Captain EO Tribute" class="mw-redirect">Captain EO Tribute</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Autopia" title="Autopia">Autopia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Monorail" title="Disneyland Monorail" class="mw-redirect">Disneyland Monorail</a> Tomorrowland Station, the Astro Orbitor and <a href="/wiki/Buzz_Lightyear_(attractions)" title="Buzz Lightyear (attractions)" class="mw-redirect">Buzz Lightyear Astro Blasters</a>. <a href="/wiki/Finding_Nemo_Submarine_Voyage" title="Finding Nemo Submarine Voyage">Finding Nemo Submarine Voyage</a> opened on June 11, 2007, resurrecting the original Submarine Voyage which closed in 1998. <a href="/wiki/Star_Tours" title="Star Tours">Star Tours</a> was closed in July 2010, and replaced with <a href="/wiki/Star_Tours%E2%80%94The_Adventures_Continue" title="Star Tours°™The Adventures Continue">Star Tours°™The Adventures Continue</a> in June 2011.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Theatrical_terminology">Theatrical terminology</span></h2>
<p>Disneyland staff use <a href="/wiki/Stagecraft" title="Stagecraft">theatrical terminology</a> to emphasize that a visit to the park is intended to be similar to witnessing a performance. Visitors are referred to as "guests" and park employees as "cast members". "On stage" refers to any area of the resort that is open to guests. "Backstage" refers to any area of the resort that is closed to guests. A crowd is referred to as an "audience". "Costume" is the attire that cast members who perform the day-to-day operations of the park must wear. "Show" is the resort's presentation to its guests, such as the color and fa?ades of buildings, placement of rides and attractions, costumes to match the themed lands. When signing credit card receipts, guests are asked for their "autograph". "Stage managers" are responsible for overseeing the operation of the park. Cast members who are in charge of a specific team are called "leads," as in a film or theater "lead role". In earlier years, the offices where administrative work took place were referred to as "production offices". "Production schedulers" build employee work schedules to meet the necessary workload, while "stage schedulers" handle day-to-day changes in that work schedule (such as a change in park hours, necessitating a change in everybody's shifts.) Each cast member's job is called a "role". When working in their roles, cast members must follow a "script", a <a href="/wiki/Code_of_conduct" title="Code of conduct">code of conduct</a> and approved, themed phraseology that cast members may use when at work. "No" and "I don't know" are notably absent from scripts.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Backstage">Backstage</span></h2>
<table class="metadata plainlinks ambox ambox-style ambox-No_footnotes" style="" role="presentation">
<tr>
<td class="mbox-image">
<div style="width: 52px;"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/40px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/60px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/80px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png 2x" /></div>
</td>
<td class="mbox-text" style=""><span class="mbox-text-span">This section includes a <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">list of references</a>, related reading or <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:External_links" title="Wikipedia:External links">external links</a>, but <b>the sources of this section remain unclear because it lacks <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Inline_citations" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">inline citations</a></b>. <span class="hide-when-compact">Please <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Fact_and_Reference_Check" title="Wikipedia:WikiProject Fact and Reference Check">improve</a> this article by introducing more precise citations.</span> <small><i>(October 2010)</i></small> </span></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Backstage areas are closed areas of attraction, store, and restaurant buildings, as well as outdoor service areas located behind such buildings. Although some areas of the park, particularly New Orleans Square, have underground operations and storage areas, there is no park-wide network of subterranean tunnels, such as Walt Disney World's <a href="/wiki/Utilidors" title="Utilidors" class="mw-redirect">utilidors</a>.</p>
<p>There are several points of entry from outside the park to the backstage areas: Ball Gate (from Ball Road), T.D.A. Gate (adjacent to the Team Disney Anaheim building), Harbor Pointe (from Harbor Boulevard), and Winston Gate (from Disneyland Drive). Berm Road encircles the park from Firehouse Gate (behind the Main Street Fire Station) to Egghouse Gate (adjacent to the Disneyland Opera House). The road is so called because it generally follows outside the path of Disneyland's <a href="/wiki/Berm" title="Berm">berm</a>. A stretch of the road, wedged between Tomorrowland and Harbor Boulevard, is called Schumacher Road. It has two narrow lanes and runs underneath the Monorail track. There are also two railroad bridges that cross Berm Road: one behind City Hall and the other behind Tomorrowland.</p>
<p>Major buildings backstage include the <a href="/wiki/Frank_Gehry" title="Frank Gehry">Frank Gehry</a>-designed <a href="/wiki/Team_Disney_Anaheim" title="Team Disney Anaheim" class="mw-redirect">Team Disney Anaheim</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> where most of the division's administration currently works, as well as the Old Administration Building, behind Tomorrowland. The Old Administration Building additionally houses the Grand Canyon and Primeval World dioramas visible on the Disneyland Railroad. The northwest corner of the park is home to most of the park's maintenance facilities, including company vehicle services, including parking lot trams and Main Street vehicles, the scrap yard, where the resort's garbage and recyclables are sorted for collection, Circle D Corral, where the resort's horses and other animals are stabled, parade float storage and maintenance, distribution center for all Resort merchandise, ride vehicle service areas, the paint shop, and the sign shop.</p>
<p>Backstage also refers to parts of show buildings that are normally not seen by guests. Backstage areas are generally off-limits to park guests. This prevents guests from seeing the industrial areas that violate the "magic" of on-stage and keeps them safe from the potentially dangerous machinery. Cast members can also find some solace while they work or rest, as backstage offers alternate routes between the park's various areas.</p>
<p>Many attractions are housed in large, soundstage-like buildings, some of which are partially or completely disguised by external theming. Generally, these buildings are painted a dull green color in areas not seen by guests, this choice helps to disguise the buildings among the foliage and make them less visually obtrusive. <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Imagineering" title="Walt Disney Imagineering">Walt Disney Imagineering</a> has termed this color "Go Away Green." Most of them have off-white flat roofs that support <a href="/wiki/HVAC" title="HVAC">HVAC</a> units and footpaths for cast members. Inside are the rides, as well as hidden walkways, service areas, control rooms, and other behind-the-scenes operations.</p>
<p>Photography is forbidden in these areas, both inside and outside, although some photos have found their way to a variety of web sites. Guests who attempt to explore backstage are warned and often escorted from the property.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> The boundary between on and off-stage is demarcated at every access point. Everything within guest view when a door or gateway is open is also considered on stage. It is from this point that characters start playing their part. That way, when the door is open, guests will not accidentally see a person out of character backstage.</p>
<p>Various amenities exist for Cast Members backstage when they are on breaks, or before and after their scheduled shifts. A number of cafeterias, now run by SodexoMAGIC, offer discounted meals throughout the day. These include Inn Between (behind the Plaza Inn), Eat Ticket (near the Team Disney Anaheim building behind Mickey's Toontown), and Westsider Grill (located approximately behind New Orleans Square). <a href="/wiki/Partners_Federal_Credit_Union" title="Partners Federal Credit Union">Partners Federal Credit Union</a>, the credit union for employees of The Walt Disney Company, provides nearly 20 ATMs backstage for cast member use and maintains an express branch at the Team Disney Anaheim building.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:DisneylandTrainLocomotive.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Disneyland Railroad" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/DisneylandTrainLocomotive.jpg/220px-DisneylandTrainLocomotive.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/DisneylandTrainLocomotive.jpg/330px-DisneylandTrainLocomotive.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/DisneylandTrainLocomotive.jpg/440px-DisneylandTrainLocomotive.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:DisneylandTrainLocomotive.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Disneyland Railroad Engine 2.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Walt Disney had a longtime interest in transportation, and trains in particular. Disney's passion for the "iron horse" led to him building a miniature <a href="/wiki/Live_steam" title="Live steam">live steam</a> <a href="/wiki/Backyard_railroad" title="Backyard railroad">backyard railroad</a>°™the "<a href="/wiki/Carolwood_Pacific_Railroad" title="Carolwood Pacific Railroad">Carolwood Pacific Railroad</a>"°™on the grounds of his <a href="/wiki/Holmby_Hills,_Los_Angeles,_California" title="Holmby Hills, Los Angeles, California" class="mw-redirect">Holmby Hills</a> estate. Throughout all the iterations of Disneyland during the seventeen or so years when Disney was conceiving it, one element remained constant: a train encircling the park.<sup id="cite_ref-Dreaming_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dreaming-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> The primary designer for the park transportation vehicles was <a href="/wiki/Bob_Gurr" title="Bob Gurr">Bob Gurr</a> who gave himself the title of Director of Special Vehicle Design in 1954.</p>
<p>Encircling Disneyland and providing a grand circle tour is the <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Railroad" title="Disneyland Railroad">Disneyland Railroad</a> (DRR), a short-line railway consisting of five oil-fired and steam-powered locomotives, in addition to three passenger trains and one passenger-carrying freight train. Originally known as the Disneyland and Santa Fe Railroad, the DRR was presented by the <a href="/wiki/Atchison,_Topeka_and_Santa_Fe_Railway" title="Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway">Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway</a> until 1974. From 1955 to 1974, the Santa Fe Rail Pass was accepted in lieu of a Disneyland "D" coupon. With a three-foot gauge, the most common <a href="/wiki/Narrow_gauge_railway" title="Narrow gauge railway">narrow gauge</a> measurement used in North America, the track runs in a continuous loop around The Magic Kingdom through each of its realms. Each turn-of-the-19th-Century train departs Main Street Station on an excursion that includes scheduled station stops at: New Orleans Square Station; Toontown Depot; and Tomorrowland Station. The Grand Circle Tour then concludes with a visit to the "<a href="/wiki/Grand_Canyon" title="Grand Canyon">Grand Canyon</a>/<a href="/wiki/Primeval_World" title="Primeval World" class="mw-redirect">Primeval World</a>" dioramas before returning passengers to Main Street, U.S.A.</p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_Mark_VII_Monorail_Red.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photo of new Monorail" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Disneyland_Mark_VII_Monorail_Red.jpg/220px-Disneyland_Mark_VII_Monorail_Red.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Disneyland_Mark_VII_Monorail_Red.jpg/330px-Disneyland_Mark_VII_Monorail_Red.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Disneyland_Mark_VII_Monorail_Red.jpg/440px-Disneyland_Mark_VII_Monorail_Red.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_Mark_VII_Monorail_Red.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Monorail Red travels over the <a href="/wiki/Finding_Nemo_Submarine_Voyage" title="Finding Nemo Submarine Voyage">Finding Nemo Submarine Voyage</a> in Tomorrowland.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>One of Disneyland's signature attractions is its <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Monorail_System" title="Disneyland Monorail System">Disneyland Monorail System</a> <a href="/wiki/Monorail" title="Monorail">monorail</a> service, which opened in Tomorrowland in 1959 as the first daily-operating monorail train system in the <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">Western Hemisphere</a>. The monorail guideway has remained almost exactly the same since 1961, aside from small alterations while Indiana Jones Adventure was being built. Five generations of monorail trains have been used in the park, since their lightweight construction means they wear out quickly. The most recent operating generation, the Mark VII, was installed in 2008. The monorail shuttles visitors between two stations, one inside the park in Tomorrowland and one in Downtown Disney. It follows a 2.5-mile (4&#160;km) long route designed to show the park from above. Currently, the Mark VII is running with the colors red, blue and orange. The monorail was originally built with one station in Tomorrowland. Its track was extended and a second station opened at the <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Hotel_(California)" title="Disneyland Hotel (California)">Disneyland Hotel</a> in 1961. With the creation of Downtown Disney in 2001, the new destination is Downtown Disney, instead of the Disneyland Hotel. The physical location of the monorail station did not change, but the original station building was demolished as part of the hotel downsizing, and the new station is now separated from the hotel by several Downtown Disney buildings, including <a href="/wiki/ESPN_Zone" title="ESPN Zone">ESPN Zone</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Rainforest_Caf%C3%A9" title="Rainforest Caf®¶" class="mw-redirect">Rainforest Caf®¶</a>.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:DisneylandDriverMainSt_wb.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Horseless carriage" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/DisneylandDriverMainSt_wb.jpg/220px-DisneylandDriverMainSt_wb.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/DisneylandDriverMainSt_wb.jpg/330px-DisneylandDriverMainSt_wb.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/DisneylandDriverMainSt_wb.jpg/440px-DisneylandDriverMainSt_wb.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:DisneylandDriverMainSt_wb.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Main Street at Disneyland as seen from a Horseless Carriage.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>All vehicles that are found on Main Street were designed to accurately reflect turn-of-the-century vehicles, including a <a href="/wiki/Double-decker_bus" title="Double-decker bus">double-decker bus</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Horsecar" title="Horsecar">horse-drawn streetcar</a>, a fire engine, and an automobile. They are available for one-way rides along Main Street, U.S.A. The horse-drawn streetcars are also used by the park entertainment, including <a href="/wiki/The_Dapper_Dans" title="The Dapper Dans">The Dapper Dans</a>. The horseless carriages are modeled after cars built in 1903, and are two-cylinder, four-horsepower (3&#160;kW) engines with manual transmission and steering. Walt Disney used to drive the fire engine around the park before it opened, and it has been used to host celebrity guests and in the parades. Most of the original main street vehicles were designed by Bob Gurr.</p>
<p>From the late 1950s to 1968 <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Airways" title="Los Angeles Airways">Los Angeles Airways</a> provided regularly scheduled helicopter passenger service between Disneyland and <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_International_Airport" title="Los Angeles International Airport">Los Angeles International Airport</a> (LAX) and other cities in the area. The helicopters initially operated from Anaheim/Disneyland Heliport, located behind Tomorrowland. Service later moved, in 1960, to a new heliport north of the Disneyland Hotel.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup> Arriving guests were transported to the Disneyland Hotel via tram. The service ended after two fatal crashes in 1968: The crash in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Airways_Flight_841" title="Los Angeles Airways Flight 841">Paramount, California, on May 22, 1968</a> killed 23 (the worst helicopter accident in aviation history at that time). The second crash in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Airways_Flight_417" title="Los Angeles Airways Flight 417">Compton, California on August 14, 1968</a>, killed 21.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup><br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Live_entertainment">Live entertainment</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Alice_plays_musical_chairs.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Disneyland Musical Chairs" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Alice_plays_musical_chairs.jpg/220px-Alice_plays_musical_chairs.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Alice_plays_musical_chairs.jpg/330px-Alice_plays_musical_chairs.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Alice_plays_musical_chairs.jpg/440px-Alice_plays_musical_chairs.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Alice_plays_musical_chairs.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Alice and characters from her movie host "Disneyland Musical Chairs" at Coca-Cola Refreshment Corner, accompanied by a ragtime pianist.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In addition to the attractions, Disneyland provides live entertainment throughout the park. Most of the mentioned entertainment is not offered daily, but only on selected days of the week, or selected periods of the year.</p>
<p>Many Disney characters can be found throughout the park, greeting visitors, interacting with children, and posing for photos. Some characters have specific areas where they are scheduled to appear, but can be found wandering as well. Some of the rarest are characters like Rabbit(from Winnie-the-Pooh), Max, Mushu, and Agent P.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> Periodically through recent decades (and most recently during the summers of 2005 and 2006), Mickey Mouse would climb the Matterhorn attraction several times a day with the support of Minnie, Goofy, and other performers. Other mountain climbers could also be seen on the Matterhorn from time to time. As of March 2007, Mickey and his "toon" friends no longer climb the Matterhorn but the climbing program continues. Every evening at dusk, there is a military-style flag retreat to lower the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_States" title="Flag of the United States">Flag of the United States</a> for the day, performed by a detail of the Disneyland Security Personnel. The ceremony usually is held between 4 and 5&#160;pm, depending on the entertainment being offered on Main Street, USA, to prevent conflicts with crowds and music. Disney does report the time the Flag Retreat is scheduled on its Times Guide, offered at the entrance turnstiles and other locations. The Disneyland Band, which has been part of the park since its opening, plays the role of the Town Band on Main Street, U.S.A. It also breaks out into smaller groups like the Main Street Strawhatters, the Hook and Ladder Co., and the Pearly Band in <a href="/wiki/Fantasyland" title="Fantasyland">Fantasyland</a>.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fantasmic_July_4.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Fantasmic" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Fantasmic_July_4.jpg/220px-Fantasmic_July_4.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Fantasmic_July_4.jpg/330px-Fantasmic_July_4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Fantasmic_July_4.jpg/440px-Fantasmic_July_4.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Fantasmic_July_4.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
<i>Fantasmic!</i> finale on July 4, 2010.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Fantasmic!" title="Fantasmic!">Fantasmic!</a></i>, which debuted in 1992, is a popular multimedia nighttime show on the <a href="/wiki/Rivers_of_America_(Disney)" title="Rivers of America (Disney)">Rivers of America</a>. The star <a href="/wiki/Mickey_Mouse" title="Mickey Mouse">Mickey Mouse</a> summons the characters and spirit of beloved Disney cartoons and uses the power of <a href="/wiki/Imagination" title="Imagination">imagination</a> to defeat the evil villains that try to turn his dream into a nightmare. The presentation is made at the Laffite's Tavern end of <a href="/wiki/Pirate%27s_Lair_on_Tom_Sawyer_Island" title="Pirate's Lair on Tom Sawyer Island">Pirate's Lair on Tom Sawyer Island</a> and uses the Rivers of America as part of the stage. It uses Frontierland and New Orleans Square as the spectator arena. It consists of synchronized lighting and special effects, with floating barges, the Mark Twain Riverboat, the Sailing Ship Columbia, fountains, lasers, fireworks, thirty-foot-tall "mist screens" upon which animated scenes are projected, and an automated 45-foot fire-breathing dragon.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneylandfireworks.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Disneyland fireworks" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Disneylandfireworks.jpg/220px-Disneylandfireworks.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Disneylandfireworks.jpg/330px-Disneylandfireworks.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Disneylandfireworks.jpg/440px-Disneylandfireworks.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Disneylandfireworks.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Disneyland fireworks from Sleeping Beauty Castle</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Elaborate fireworks shows synchronized with Disney songs and often have appearances from <a href="/wiki/Tinker_Bell" title="Tinker Bell">Tinker Bell</a> or <a href="/wiki/Dumbo" title="Dumbo">Dumbo</a>, flying in the sky above Sleeping Beauty Castle. Since 2000, presentations have become more elaborate, featuring new pyrotechnics, launch techniques and story lines. In 2004, Disneyland introduced a new air launch pyrotechnics system, reducing ground level smoke and noise and decreasing negative environmental impacts. At the time the technology debuted, Disney announced it would donate the patents to a non-profit organization for use throughout the industry.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
