(July 2013)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup>
<ul>
<li>June 12, 2009&#160;®C September 20, 2009: <i><a href="/wiki/Magical:_An_Exploding_Celebration_In_The_Sky" title="Magical: An Exploding Celebration In The Sky" class="mw-redirect">Magical: An Exploding Celebration In The Sky</a></i></li>
<li>September 25, 2009&#160;®C November 1, 2009: <i><a href="/wiki/Halloween_Screams" title="Halloween Screams">Halloween Screams</a></i></li>
<li>November 12, 2010&#160;®C January 2, 2011: <i><a href="/wiki/Believe..._In_Holiday_Magic" title="Believe... In Holiday Magic">Believe... In Holiday Magic</a></i></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Since 2009, Disneyland has moved to a rotating repertoire of firework spectaculars.</p>
<ul>
<li><b>Yearly fireworks repertoire</b>
<ul>
<li>Late winter/spring: <i><a href="/wiki/Remember..._Dreams_Come_True" title="Remember... Dreams Come True">Remember... Dreams Come True</a></i></li>
<li>Summer: <i><a href="/wiki/Magical:_Disney%27s_New_Nighttime_Spectacular_of_Magical_Celebrations" title="Magical: Disney's New Nighttime Spectacular of Magical Celebrations">Magical: Disney's New Nighttime Spectacular of Magical Celebrations</a></i></li>
<li>Independence Day Week: <i><a href="/wiki/Disney%27s_Celebrate_America:_A_4th_of_July_Concert_in_the_Sky" title="Disney's Celebrate America: A 4th of July Concert in the Sky" class="mw-redirect">Disney's Celebrate America: A 4th of July Concert in the Sky</a></i></li>
<li>Mickey's Halloween Party Exclusive: <i><a href="/wiki/Halloween_Screams" title="Halloween Screams">Halloween Screams</a></i></li>
<li>Holiday: <i><a href="/wiki/Believe..._In_Holiday_Magic" title="Believe... In Holiday Magic">Believe... In Holiday Magic</a></i></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>During the holiday season, there is a special fireworks presentation called <i>Believe... In Holiday Magic</i>, which has been running since 2000, except for a hiatus in 2005 during the park's 50th anniversary celebration.</p>
<p>Scheduling of fireworks shows depends on the time of year. During the slower off-season periods, the fireworks are only offered on weekends. During the busier times, Disney offers additional nights. The park offers fireworks nightly during its busy periods, which include Easter/Spring Break, Summer and Christmas time. Disneyland spends about $41,000 per night on the fireworks show. The show is normally offered at 8:45&#160;pm if the park is scheduled to close at 10&#160;pm or later, but shows have started as early as 5:45&#160;pm. A major consideration is weather/winds, especially at higher elevations, which can force the cancellation of the show. The park will usually wait an additional 15 minutes or so to see if the winds die down. Shows, with a few minor exceptions, such as July 4 and New Year's Eve, must finish by 10&#160;pm due to the conditions of the permit issued by the City of Anaheim.</p>
<p>The Golden Horseshoe Saloon offers a live stage show with an <a href="/wiki/American_Old_West" title="American Old West" class="mw-redirect">Old West</a> feel. The Golden Horseshoe Revue was an <a href="/wiki/American_frontier" title="American frontier">American frontier</a>-themed <a href="/wiki/Vaudeville" title="Vaudeville">vaudeville</a> show starring Sluefoot Sue and Pecos Bill. It ran until the mid-1980s, when it was replaced by a similar show starring Lily Langtree (or Miss Lily) and Sam the Bartender. Most recently, <a href="/wiki/Billy_Hill_and_the_Hillbillies" title="Billy Hill and the Hillbillies">Billy Hill and the Hillbillies</a> have played their guitars and <a href="/wiki/Banjo" title="Banjo">banjos</a> in a bluegrass-and-comedy show. Additionally, in front of the Golden Horsehose Saloon, The Laughing Stock Co. enacts small humorous skits with an Old West theme.</p>
<p>Disneyland has featured a number of different parades traveling down the park's central Main Street&#160;®C Fantasyland corridor. There have been daytime and nighttime parades that celebrated Disney films or seasonal holidays with characters, music, and large floats. One of the most popular parades was the <a href="/wiki/Main_Street_Electrical_Parade" title="Main Street Electrical Parade">Main Street Electrical Parade</a>, which now resides at the <a href="/wiki/Magic_Kingdom" title="Magic Kingdom">Magic Kingdom</a> at Walt Disney World in <a href="/wiki/Lake_Buena_Vista" title="Lake Buena Vista" class="mw-redirect">Lake Buena Vista</a>, Florida. From May 5, 2005 through November 7, 2008, as part of the Disneyland's 50th Anniversary, <i><a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney%27s_Parade_of_Dreams" title="Walt Disney's Parade of Dreams">Walt Disney's Parade of Dreams</a></i> was presented, celebrating several of the classic Disney stories including <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lion_King" title="The Lion King">The Lion King</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid_(1989_film)" title="The Little Mermaid (1989 film)">The Little Mermaid</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_(1951_film)" title="Alice in Wonderland (1951 film)">Alice in Wonderland</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Pinocchio" title="Pinocchio">Pinocchio</a></i>. In 2009, <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney%27s_Parade_of_Dreams" title="Walt Disney's Parade of Dreams">Walt Disney's Parade of Dreams</a> was replaced by <i>Celebrate! A Street Party</i>, which premiered on March 27, 2009. Disney does not call <i>Celebrate! A Street Party</i> a parade, but rather a "street event." During the Christmas season, Disneyland presents "A Christmas Fantasy" Parade. Walt Disney's Parade of Dreams was replaced by <i>Mickey°Øs Soundsational Parade</i> which debuted on May 27, 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Tomorrowland_Terrace" title="Tomorrowland Terrace">Tomorrowland Terrace</a> is a stage in Tomorrowland. It is a two-story stage where the lower stage rises from below floor level. It was popular in the 1960s with music performers of the day. Over the years, it was eventually replaced with Club Buzz, a <a href="/wiki/Buzz_Lightyear" title="Buzz Lightyear">Buzz Lightyear</a>-themed stage and show featuring the space character from the <i><a href="/wiki/Toy_Story" title="Toy Story">Toy Story</a></i> films. In 2006, it was restored to the Tomorrowland Terrace with the same style and design as the original. It is now home to the <a href="/wiki/Star_Wars_Weekends#Attractions" title="Star Wars Weekends">Jedi Training Academy</a> interactive stage show where children are chosen as <a href="/wiki/Jedi" title="Jedi">Jedi</a> <i>padawan</i> and taught how to use a <a href="/wiki/Lightsaber" title="Lightsaber">lightsaber</a>. Each child then has the opportunity to face <i><a href="/wiki/Star_Wars" title="Star Wars">Star Wars</a></i> antagonists <a href="/wiki/Darth_Vader" title="Darth Vader">Darth Vader</a> or <a href="/wiki/Darth_Maul" title="Darth Maul">Darth Maul</a>. Also, local bands have returned to play in the evenings, just as Tomorrowland Terrace hosted in the 1960s.</p>
<p>Various other street performers appear throughout the park, some seasonally. They include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The All-American College Band, composed of student musicians from colleges and universities around the U.S., which performs during the summer season.</li>
<li>The Ragtime Pianist at Coca-Cola Refreshment Corner (also known as "Coke Corner") on Main Street.</li>
<li>Characters from <a href="/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_(1951_movie)" title="Alice in Wonderland (1951 movie)" class="mw-redirect">Alice in Wonderland</a> who stage a wacky game of "<a href="/wiki/Musical_chairs" title="Musical chairs">Disneyland Musical Chairs</a>" at Coca-Cola Corner each afternoon.</li>
<li>The Bootstrappers, a rowdy band of pirates inspired by the <i><a href="/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean" title="Pirates of the Caribbean">Pirates of the Caribbean</a></i> attraction and movies, that sings sea shanties and does buckaneer-style comedy.</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Dapper_Dans" title="Dapper Dans" class="mw-redirect">Dapper Dans</a> barbershop quartet, which performs on Main Street.</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Firehouse_Five_Plus_Two" title="Firehouse Five Plus Two">Firehouse Five Plus Two</a> (originally a band composed of <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Imagineering" title="Walt Disney Imagineering">Imagineers</a>) found at the Firehouse on Main Street.</li>
<li>The Trash Can Trio, a <a href="/wiki/Stomp_(dance_troupe)" title="Stomp (dance troupe)" class="mw-redirect">Stomp</a>-like group that performs using trash cans in Tomorrowland.</li>
<li>Various <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a> and jazz-influenced bands including the Jambalaya Jazz Band, the Side Street Strutters, and the Royal Street Bachelors, who play in New Orleans Square.</li>
<li>Many highschool and middle school ensembles perform annually in the <a href="/wiki/Disney_Jazz_Celebration" title="Disney Jazz Celebration">Disney Jazz Celebration</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Special holiday-themed groups are also added each year, such as the Main Street Carolers during the Christmas season.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tickets">Tickets</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:DisneyTicketBook_wbelf.jpg" class="image"><img alt="old Disneyland ticket book" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/DisneyTicketBook_wbelf.jpg/220px-DisneyTicketBook_wbelf.jpg" width="220" height="87" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/DisneyTicketBook_wbelf.jpg/330px-DisneyTicketBook_wbelf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/DisneyTicketBook_wbelf.jpg/440px-DisneyTicketBook_wbelf.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:DisneyTicketBook_wbelf.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Disneyland ticket book circa 1975®C1977. The tickets were printed as "coupons".</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>From Disneyland's opening day until 1982, the price of the attractions was in addition to the price of park admission.<sup id="cite_ref-book_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-book-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> Guests paid a small admission fee to get into the park, but admission to most of the rides and attractions required guests to purchase tickets, either individually or in a book, that consisted of several coupons, initially labeled "A" through "C". "A" coupons allowed admission to the smaller rides and attractions such as the vehicles on Main Street, whereas "C" coupons were used for the most common attractions like the Peter Pan ride, or the Tea Cups. As more thrilling rides were introduced, such as the Monorail or the Matterhorn bobsled, "D" and then eventually "E" coupons were introduced. Coupons could be combined to equal the equivalent of another ticket (e.g. two "A" tickets equal one "B" ticket). From the thrill ride experience at Disneyland, the colloquial expression "an <a href="/wiki/E_ticket" title="E ticket">E ticket</a> ride" is used to describe any exceptionally thrilling experience.</p>
<p>Disneyland later featured a "Keys to the Kingdom" booklet of tickets, which consisted of 10 unvalued coupons sold for a single flat rate. These coupons could be used for any attraction regardless of its regular value.</p>
<p>In 1982, Disney dropped the idea for individual ride tickets to a single admission price with unlimited access to all attractions, "except shooting galleries".<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> While this idea was not original to Disney, its business advantages were obvious: in addition to guaranteeing that everyone paid a large sum even if they stayed for only a few hours and rode only a few rides, the park no longer had to print tickets or ticket books, staff ticket booths, or provide staff to collect tickets or monitor attractions for people sneaking on without tickets. Later, Disney introduced other entry options such as multi-day passes, Annual Passes (which allow unlimited entry to the Park for an annual fee), and Southern California residents' discounts.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Closures">Closures</span></h2>
<p>Disneyland has had three unscheduled closures:</p>
<ul>
<li>In 1963, following the <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Assassination of John F. Kennedy">assassination of John F. Kennedy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>In 1994, for inspection after the <a href="/wiki/1994_Northridge_earthquake" title="1994 Northridge earthquake">1994 Northridge earthquake</a>.</li>
<li>In 2001, after the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a>. Due to the difference in time zones, Walt Disney World parks in Florida (<a href="/wiki/Eastern_Time_Zone" title="Eastern Time Zone">Eastern Time Zone</a>) had already opened for the day at the time of the collapse of the Twin Towers of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center" title="World Trade Center">World Trade Center</a> and were subsequently closed, while Disneyland and <a href="/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure" title="Disney California Adventure">Disney California Adventure</a> had yet to open for the day, with the time only being 7-7:30 a.m. <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Time_Zone" title="Pacific Time Zone">Pacific</a> there.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup></li>
</ul>
<p>Additionally, Disneyland has had numerous planned closures:</p>
<ul>
<li>In the early years, the park was often scheduled to be closed on Mondays and Tuesdays during the off-season.<sup id="cite_ref-GoCalifornia.about.com_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GoCalifornia.about.com-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> This was in conjunction with nearby <a href="/wiki/Knott%27s_Berry_Farm" title="Knott's Berry Farm">Knott's Berry Farm</a>, which closed on Wednesdays and Thursdays to keep costs down for both parks, while offering Orange County visitors a place to go 7 days a week.</li>
<li>On May 4, 2005, for the 50th Anniversary Celebration media event.<sup id="cite_ref-DizHub.com_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DizHub.com-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>The park has closed early to accommodate various special events, such as special press events, tour groups, VIP groups, and private parties. It is common for a corporation to rent the entire park for the evening. In such cases, special passes are issued which are valid for admission to all rides and attractions. At the ticket booths and on published schedules, regular guests are notified of the early closures. In the late afternoon, cast members announce that the park is closing, then clear the park of everyone without the special passes.</li>
</ul>
<p><br style="clear:both;" /></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Promotions">Promotions</span></h2>
<p>Every year in October, Disneyland has a Halloween promotion when parts of the park are decorated in a Halloween theme. Space Mountain and the Haunted Mansion are temporarily rethemed as part of the promotion. A Halloween party is offered on selected nights in late September and October for a separate fee, with a special fireworks show that is only shown at the party.</p>
<p>From early November until the beginning of January, the park is decorated for the holidays. Seasonal entertainment includes the <i><a href="/wiki/Believe..._In_Holiday_Magic" title="Believe... In Holiday Magic">Believe... In Holiday Magic</a></i> firework show and <i><a href="/wiki/A_Christmas_Fantasy_Parade" title="A Christmas Fantasy Parade">A Christmas Fantasy Parade</a></i>, and the <a href="/wiki/Haunted_Mansion" title="Haunted Mansion">Haunted Mansion</a> and <a href="/wiki/It%27s_a_Small_World" title="It's a Small World">It's a Small World</a> are temporarily redecorated in a holiday theme. The Sleeping Beauty castle is also known to become snow-capped and decorated with colorful lights during the holidays as well.<br style="clear:both;" /></p>
